content.question: <math alttext="L i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L</mtext><mtext>i</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="7300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="N a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="4560" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4560</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3050" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3050</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="R b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2630" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2630</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> The decrease in the second ionization energy of alkali metals going down the group, as shown in the table above, can be best attributed to a decrease in the coulombic force of attraction due to

choices.label: an increase in effective nuclear charge
an increase in the average distance of the outermost electron from the nucleus
a decrease in electron-electron repulsion within the outermost shell

content.answer: an increase in the average distance of the outermost electron from the nucleus
